Package org.jtrim2.cache

Interface VolatileReference<ReferentType>

Type Parameters:
ReferentType - the type of the stored object
public interface VolatileReference<ReferentType>
Defines a reference to an object which can disappear any time beyond the control of the client.

This reference is similar to the references in Java (such as the soft reference) but cannot have a reference queue.

The intended use of this class is for caching an object which retains a considerable amount of memory and so the reference to the stored object can disappear when there is not enough memory. Clients therefore must always be aware that the stored object might be unavailable through this reference and have a plan to fetch it again in this case.

Note that although the referenced object may disappear any time, it is permitted to reappear at a later time (although in most implementations it will not happen). Despite this users of a volatile reference should discard the volatile reference after detecting that the referenced object disappeared and should not hope for the referenced object to reappear.

The reference can also be cleared in which case the referenced object must not be reachable through the volatile reference anymore (and not allowed to reappear).

Clients are recommended to clear references they no longer use because this allows underlying caches to discard unneeded reference.

Thread safety

Implementations of this interface are required to be completely thread-safe and the methods can be called from any thread.

Synchronization transparency

The methods of this interface are required to be synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
See Also:

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    void
    clear()
    Removes the referenced object from this volatile reference.
    ReferentType
    get()
    Returns the referenced object or null in case it disappeared.

  • Method Details

    • get

      ReferentType get()
      Returns the referenced object or null in case it disappeared. This method must return the same object (in terms of "==") over the lifetime of this volatile reference or null. Note however that even if this method returns null, it is allowed to return the original reference at a later point (though in most implementation this will not occur).
      Returns:
      the referenced object or null in case it disappeared

    • clear

      void clear()
      Removes the referenced object from this volatile reference. After this method call get() must return null forever and the referenced object is not allowed to reappear.

      Clients are recommended to call this method if they know that this volatile reference will not be used anymore. Calling this method may help the underlying cache to remove unneeded references to the referenced object.
